Thinking of putting together an fanmade album of the AM tour. What should be included?
WRITING.TEXT:
In a similar style to the fanmade albums high green sheffield and fools on parade.
We're looking for the best performances of the main songs of the tour. What should I include?
Also, thinking something along the lines of "Early Morning Music: Artic Monkeys Live, The AM Tour" for the title? Music of the Morning? Early Hours? Before Sunrise: the AM tour? I know that's not what "AM" stands for, but I feel that fits the tone of the album well.
Some suggestions:
One for the Road - Sydney Entertainment Centre
Knee Socks - Austin City Limits
Snap Out of it - Album de la Semaine
505 - Glastonbury 2013
Knee Socks/My Propellor - Rock Wertcher
Fluorescent Adolescent - Sydney Entertainment Centre
This really doesn't work very well at all.....
I think the minute it stopped working Turner would've figured it out. He went over to tease him for sure - he already knew what was wrong

The way Turner reacts is just fucking great. He just finds the whole things hilarious and he's OBVIOUSLY sick of playing Dancefloor anyway, so he just mixes it up and fucks around with the lyrics, even teasing Jamie by going over and playing in front of him... and then he started doing the ridiculous crowd-hand-summoning things...
Also - does anyone know whether Alex just stuck to his normal part during Dancefloor when Jamie's guitar wasn't working? or did he try and cover areas of Jamie's part that were necessary?
He literally can't hear anything he's doing. He would've just got frustrated...

WRITING.TITLE: [Comic Spoilers] [Community Re-read] Walking Dead Issues 7-12!
WRITING.TEXT:
For me, the latter issues of this arc surrounding the problem of being on the road, running out of food, finding Tyreese etc. are much better than when they get to Hershel's farm.
Much with like I said with Shane in volumes 1-6, I feel both the "walkers in the barn" situation and Maggie and Glenn getting together are severely underdeveloped. The show just built everything up so that the walkers in the barn actually felt much more impactful when they came out. I also found it weird that Maggie and Glenn all of a sudden just loved each and Glenn was willing to leave the group when they depart from the farm.
Laters arcs in the series, such as the [](/c "Alexandria safe zone arc, with Rick gradually taking over leadership") feel way more developed.
Also - Donna's death :D
Where's the AM logo subtly worked into the middle?

WRITING.TITLE: What were the visible outcomes for Hitler's desire for a "volksgemeinschaft"?
WRITING.TEXT:
I'm studying Germany between the wars and obviously Hitler had a dream of creating a volksgemeinschaft, but in what ways did this dream actually affect the German people at the time? What did Hitler do to achieve this dream?
Could things like Gleichschaltung be counted as outcomes of his desire for a volksgemeinschaft?
True dat. Donna really rubbed me the wrong way.

WRITING.TITLE: [Comic Spoilers] [Community Re-read] Walking Dead Issues 1-6!
WRITING.TEXT:
I figured it would be cool to discuss the comics as a community, rereading and discussing as we go. Naturally I think we could be discussing events in relation to stuff that comes after (eg a thread on issues 1-6 might still have spoilers for issue 100) but we should certainly put spoiler tags on (cause although I'm almost up to date, I still haven't read the All Out War arc, a situation that other would be in, perhaps at different areas though). Spoilers from the issues we are discussing don't have to be spoiler tagged.
Some general notes:
Naturally this was Moore's short stint with the artwork. Although, I do like the detail that is presented, I don't think the style is right. It is cool, but the grim and gritty style that Adlard presents from issue 7 onwards suits the feel much better. Although I must admit I agree with those that say the artwork has gone downhill.
Another thing I love about these issues is they stand really well on their own. They set up the story well, a lot of shit happens and they have an artwork style that is different to the rest of the series. I just really like this arc as whole.
I do feel that the Shane arc was really underdeveloped however. I like it much better in the show as it was really fleshed out and built up over a long time, whereas here I feel the audience barely gets to know Shane before Carl shoots him...
I thinking creating these discussions every 4 days would be appropriate, or maybe a week? Each discussion would focus on the next 6 issues. Thoughts?
ITT: A famous children's book authors answers nothing, but merely poses more vague questions in the same style as the books he is famous for.

WRITING.TITLE: Where to start?
WRITING.TEXT:
I haven't really listen to any of these guys before, bar for one listen of some random tracks, which made me realised I liked their sound.
I was recommended The Black Keys as I love the Arctic Monkeys and apparently they are similar. If anyone is wondering, I like pretty much any of AM's eras, bar Humbug which is probably my least favourite.
Mmmm DAT ACCENT
The chorus of Crying Lightning works if you rearrange the chord progression too.
May as well!

No problem! I've been teaching myself guitar recently and singing along, and this was one of things I noticed about my singing when recording myself and listening to it back; I was playing in keys that suited my guitar ability, but not my voice!

The parts where you sing in higher regions sound better than than parts in the lower regions, which is probably just due to the key you're playing in being ill-fitted for your register. Perhaps move the chord progression up a few keys, as when you singer higher your voice is quite good.
Example of low region: "I thought I saw you in the battleship"
Example of high region: "she was close, close enough to be your ghost"

I did notice they used the similar chord progression and same key. In fact, on an acoustic guitar if you play Em, C, Am, you can play R U Mine, Do I Wanna Know, One For The Road, Why'd You Only Call Me When You're High all in a row!
You'll regret it. I guarantee it.

WRITING.TITLE: Overwhelmed with no idea where to start...
WRITING.TEXT:
So I've been trying to get into Green Day. I've really liked what I've listened to, and I've downloaded their discography. Problem is, it's just so damn large I don't know where to begin, what the "classics" are, which albums are generally considered better among the fanbase etc.
Really, the only album I've listened to so far is American Idiot, and I really really like it, but going beyond that... I'm just lost... Help me!

1. Suck it and See 2. Black Treacle 3. Reckless Serenade 4. Don't Sit Down... 5. Piledriver Waltz 6. Love is a Laserquest 7.She's Thunderstorms 8. Hellcat Spangled Shalalala 9. That's Where You're Wrong 10. Library Pictures 11. Brick by Brick 12. All My Own Stunts
And if it were allowed Evil Twin would be #4...
I didn't realise the one from Submarine was different until last night, but certainly agree with you. Much nice tone and the low key makes Alex's voice sound beautiful.
Pretty sure Walter Walt was a murdered and meth cook ;)
This. Fucking this.
So fucking true
Blends in, bought something from there before
Sydney, Australia. First time seeing them, really looking forward to it.
Holy. Fucking. Shit.
Ohhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhh
That might be part of it, but it's CERTAINLY also to do with Chav culture

Despair in the Departure Lounge is about having to break a relationship off as you're moving somewhere else
Do I Wanna Know is the singer asking himself if he wants to get romantically involved with a woman
From the Ritz to the Rubble is about trying to get into a nightclub and how the city looks different the morning after
Dancing Shoes is about not having the nerves to talk to women in a nightclub, even though it's the only reason you came
A Certain Romance is about English chav culture
When the Sun Goes Down is about a prostitute and a "scummy man" (a pimp)
Riot Van explains itself
Cornerstone is about a girl who a man loved. The girl is dead but the man searches for her everywhere, and sees her in every new girl he meets.
Arabella is about one hell of a sexy girl
And Crying Lightning is anyone's fucking guess...

WRITING.TITLE: Documentaries that deal with both history and memory?
WRITING.TEXT:
Hi /r/Documentaries!
I need your help. For my English class I need to find a doco that focuses on history and memory.
More specifically, the interplay between the two (how memory fills history's gaps, how memory can act as history, how collective memory can contrast history etc.)
I'm really struggling and any help would be appreciated!

WRITING.TITLE: Do I Wanna Know? in a Bacardi ad

WRITING.TEXT:
It depends what you find easiest to get into. I've come around to all their albums eventually, but I had to use the others as stepping stones. Here's my guide:
Whatever people say I am, that's what I'm not: -True rock sound -Very raw -Catchy with some good "story" tracks such as Mardy Bum, When the Sun Goes Down and Riot Van
Favourite Worst Nightmare -Similar to their first, maybe a bit darker though -Highlight tracks: Fluorescent Adolescent, Balaclava, Brianstorm
Humbug -Hardest to get into for me, very different to the previous two -Very psychedelic rock -Highlight tracks: Crying Lightning, Cornerstone, Pretty Visitors, My Propellor
Suck It and See -I like to describe the feel of this album as "Electric" -Some great lyrical songs -Highlight tracks include: Suck It and See, Black Treacle, Don't Sit Down Cause I've Moved Your Chair, Reckless Serenade
AM -Easiest to get into as it has broad appeal -More pop, whilst still containing that Arctic Monkeys feel under the pop facade -Best tracks include: Why'd You Only Call Me When You're High, No 1 Party Anthem, R U Mine?, One For the Road and Arabella

It's like they're showing off the information that you've put on there. Sure you put it there, but this a RENDERED video. It's way more creepy than say a webpage summarising all your posts...
I dunno maybe it's just me.
